conclusion: When the switch is closed the two initially-uncharged capacitors begin to charge.
Because all current that charges the capacitors has to pass the series resistor R₁, the algebraic amount of charge that crosses R₁ is equal to the net charge finally stored on the two capacitors.

premise: The switch is closed and capacitors begin to charge.
conclusion: Final steady-state voltage on each capacitor V = E = 10 V

premise: Final steady-state voltage on each capacitor V = E = 10 V
conclusion: Charge on each capacitor Q₁ = C₁ V = (30 µF)(10 V) = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴ C

premise: Final steady-state voltage on each capacitor V = E = 10 V
conclusion: Charge on each capacitor Q₂ = C₂ V = (30 µF)(10 V) = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴ C

premise: Charge on each capacitor Q₁ = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴ C and Q₂ = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴ C
conclusion: Total charge delivered through R₁ Q_total = Q₁ + Q₂ = 6.0 × 10⁻⁴ C = 600 µC
After the switch is opened again no further current flows.

premise: Total charge delivered through R₁ Q_total = 6.0 × 10⁻⁴ C
conclusion: The charge that has crossed R₁ during the whole charging interval is Q = 6.0 × 10⁻⁴ C (600 µC).
